nodes.text: Differences in colonial institutions, shaped by settler mortality and settlement patterns, causally explain large cross-country differences in income per capita today

Theory premises: (a) European colonization produced two broad institutional types (extractive states vs settler 'Neo-Europes'); (b) colonization strategy depended on feasibility of European settlement (disease/mortality); (c) colonial institutions persisted after independence

Identification strategy / method: use historical European settler mortality rates (soldiers, sailors, bishops) as an instrument for current institutions to estimate causal effect of institutions on GDP per capita (2SLS)

Data sources and construction method: settler mortality series compiled mainly from Philip Curtin (military/naval records), Vatican/bishops mortality for Latin America, earliest available mortality number per colony; institutions proxied by Political Risk Services expropriation index and Polity III measures
Claim: Higher settler mortality reduced European settlement in colonies (mortality deterred settlers), altering colonization strategy toward extractive institutions

Evidence (historical examples): very high early European mortality in West Africa (Sierra Leone examples: first-year mortality 46–72%), Pilgrims avoided Guyana for high mortality, Beauchamp Committee rejected some sites for convicts because of health risks

Claim: Presence of European settlers led to imposition/replication of European-like institutions (private property, checks on power), while places without settlers became extractive states focused on resource extraction

Evidence (institutional differences): settler colonies (Australia, New Zealand, Canada, USA, parts of Latin America) established property rights and representative institutions; non-settler colonies (Congo, much of Africa, parts of Latin America) show extractive policies, monopolies, forced labor, high taxation under colonial rule
Claim: Early colonial institutions persisted into the post-independence era and form the basis for current institutions

Evidence for persistence and mechanisms: documented persistence of extractive policies after independence (e.g., Latin America monopolies, forced labor); mechanisms include sunk costs to build inclusive institutions, ruling elite size incentives, and complementarity with irreversible investments

Result (first-stage): Log settler mortality is strongly negatively correlated with current institutions; historical settler mortality explains about 25–30 percent of cross-country variation in institutions (strong first-stage for IV)

Result (2SLS main): Instrumenting institutions with settler mortality yields a large, precisely estimated causal effect of institutions on income per capita (baseline 2SLS ~0.94 on log income per capita; implies large long-run gains from better institutions), larger than OLS (attenuation) and robust to many controls

Conclusion: Once institutions are instrumented/controlled for, geographic proxies (distance from equator, Africa dummy) lose independent explanatory power for income per capita; apparent geography effects operate largely through institutions

Evidence on robustness and validity: results robust to excluding Neo-Europes and Africa, to controls for colonizer identity, legal origin, climate, religion, natural resources, soil, ethnolinguistic fragmentation, current disease measures; overidentification tests and alternative instruments (settlements, early institutions, yellow-fever history) provide no evidence of a direct effect of settler mortality on income

Limitation: The analysis treats institutions as a 'black box' (expropriation risk/protection index); it does not identify specific practical policy steps to create better institutions or the microchannels translating institutional change into growth
